paragraph: In this environment Nokomis brought him up. Here she taught him the first words, and told him the first fairy tales, and the sounds of the water and the wood were intermingled, so that the child learned not only to understand man’s speech, but also that of Nature:“At the door on summer evenings         Sat the little Hiawatha;         Heard the whispering of the pine-trees,         Heard the lapping of the water,         Sounds of music, words of wonder:         ‘Minne-wawa!’[641] said the pine-trees,         ‘Mudway-aushka!’[642] said the water.”
question: What specific natural elements did the child hear and learn from at the door on summer evenings?
answer: At the door on summer evenings, the child heard the whispering of the pine-trees and the lapping of the water. These natural sounds were part of his learning process, helping him to understand both human speech and the language of nature.
